clinical_study.brief_title: A Quality Improvement Process to Support Delivery of Cardiovascular Care in Community Mental Health Organizations
clinical_study.official_title: Using an Innovative Quality Improvement Process to Increase Delivery of Evidence-based Cardiovascular Risk Factor Care in Community Mental Health Organizations

brief_summary.textblock: This pilot study will examine whether an implementation strategy will improve delivery of evidence-based care for cardiovascular risk factors for people with serious mental illness.

detailed_description.textblock: In this pilot study, the investigators will work with health home programs and pilot test an adapted Comprehensive Unit Safety Program (CUSP) implementation strategy to improve mental health providers' delivery of evidence-based cardiovascular risk factor care for hypertension, dyslipidemia and diabetes for individuals with serious mental illness. The project will also characterize implementation processes, organizational and provider-level factors, and cardiovascular disease risk factor care and control.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in quality improvement culture as assessed by the modified version of the validated Survey on Patient Safety
primary_outcome.description: Each of the 34 items in the modified survey is scored individually on 1-5 Likert scales. An average score is calculated by summing responses across all 34 items and dividing by the total number of items. The average score ranges from 1-5. A higher average score signifies an organizational culture that is more supportive of quality improvement.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in self-efficacy as assessed by an adapted version of Compeau & Higgins' task-focused self-efficacy scale
primary_outcome.description: Each of the nine items is scored individually on a 1-10 Likert scale, where 1=not at all confident and 10=totally confident. An average score is calculated by summing responses across all 9 items and dividing by the total number of items. The average score ranges from 1-10. A higher score signifies greater self-efficacy.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in acceptability as assessed by the Acceptability of Intervention Measure
secondary_outcome.description: We will use a validated 4-item instrument measuring intervention acceptability, using the Acceptability of Intervention Measure. Each of the 4 items will be measured on a 5-point Likert scale, where 1=completely disagree and 5=completely agree. An average score is calculated by summing responses across all four items and dividing by the total number of items. The average score ranges from 1-5. A higher score signifies greater acceptability.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Hypertension control
secondary_outcome.description: Measured with blood pressure (BP) readings (Controlled BP defined as <130/80 mmHg).

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in dyslipidemia control
secondary_outcome.description: Measured with cholesterol readings (controlled dyslipidemia defined as total cholesterol <200 mg/dL and low-density lipoprotein (LDL) <130 mg/dL).

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in diabetes control
secondary_outcome.description: Measured using HbA1c tests (controlled diabetes defined as HbA1c<7.0).

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
Study population 1:
- Psychiatric rehabilitation program and health home team staff, including providers and leadership are those employed by the psychiatric rehabilitation program or health home program.
- English-speaking.
Study population 2:
- People with serious mental illness participating in psychiatric rehabilitation health home programs.
- English-speaking
Exclusion Criteria:
- None
